lessons.summary: The Careers team at Udacity is here to help you move forward in your career - whether it's finding a new job, exploring a new career path, or applying new skills to your current job.

parts.title: Design for Availability, Reliability, and Resiliency

modules.title: Design for Availability, Reliability and Resiliency

lessons.summary: In this lesson, you will review the course prerequisites and history of the high level concepts.  You will learn what makes these topics important and you'll get a glimpse at the course project.
lessons.title: Introduction to Availability, Reliability, and Resiliency

concepts.title: Introduction to Availability, Reliability and Resiliency

lessons.summary: Overview of AWS Regions and Availability Zones and how they are used to enable high availability and geographic redundancy.
lessons.title: AZs and Regions

lessons.summary: In this lesson you will learn how to make individual AWS services resilient.  You'll look at native and non-native services and learn about the difference between them with regard to high availability
lessons.title: Building For Resiliency

lessons.summary: A look at how resilience and availability are measure by your business and how these engineering concepts integrate with the day-to-day business world.
lessons.title: Business Objectives

lessons.summary: Now that you've seen how to build highly available systems, you'll take a look at how to make sure that these systems are up and running and what to do when problems do occur.
lessons.title: Monitor, React, and Recover

project.title: Recoverability In AWS
project.description:
In this project you will create highly available solutions to common use cases. You will build a Multi-AvailabilityZone, Multi-Region database and show how to use it in multiple geographically separate AWS regions. You will also build a website hosting solution that is versioned so that any data destruction and accidents can be quickly and easily undone.

Throughout the instructions you will find notes (anything starting with ***"SAVE"***) as to what to submit for this project.  The project completion submission should include:
- Various screenshots as denoted in the instructions
- Database command line logs from the various interactions with the databases of this project
- A written description of the RTO and RPO related to this project as described within the instructions

Before you submit the project, read the [project rubric](https://review.udacity.com/#!/rubrics/2811/view).

lessons.summary: Welcome to the course! In this lesson we'll start with a discussion of the importance of performance efficiency, look at the history of performance in the cloud and get you set up for the rest of the course.
lessons.title: Introduction to Design for Cost, Performance, and Scalability

lessons.summary: Managing cloud spend is quoted as one of the major challenges facing organizations today. This lesson will help you understand the challenges of costs in the cloud and give you some tools to help you manage those costs.
lessons.title: Cost and Monitoring

concepts.title: Intro to Costs in the Cloud

lessons.summary: Performance and cloud resources are closely related to costs and resource allocation.  In this lesson, we will explore ways to utilize AWS services to optimize performance.
lessons.title: Cloud Performance and Optimization

concepts.title: Exercise: Create an RDS with Read Replica
Solution: Create an RDS with Read Replica

lessons.summary: Serverless computing is an architecture model where a cloud provider offers scalable, flexible, and low-cost backend services as needed.
lessons.title: Serverless Computing

lessons.summary: In this project, you will plan, design, provision, and monitor infrastructure in AWS using industry-standard and open source tools.
lessons.title: Design, Provision and Monitor AWS Infrastructure at Scale

project.title: Design, Provision and Monitor AWS Infrastructure at Scale
project.description:
To begin the project you can fork the **[project starter code repository](https://github.com/udacity/cand-c2-project)**



----
### Required Screenshots and File Uploads

Your Git repository should include the code for the Terraform Exercises, infrastructure diagrams, cost estimates/rationales and all required screenshots:

- Updated Terraform code 
- Cost-effective AWS infrastructure diagram
- Serverless schematic diagram
- Initial_Cost_Estimate.csv
- Reduced_Cost_Estimate.csv including rationale
- Increased_Cost_Estimate.csv including rationale
- IAMS Password policy screenshot (from Account settings page)
- CloudTrail Log (CSV file)
- Cloudwatch Billing alarm (screenshot)
- AWS Console screenshots from the Terraform exercises:
  - Terraform_1_1
  - Terraform_1_2
  - Terraform_2_1
  - Terraform_2_2
  - Terraform_2_3
  - Terraform_destroyed

Before submitting the project, please check the **[Project Rubric](https://review.udacity.com/#!/rubrics/2757/view)** to confirm that you have completed all of the requirements.

lessons.summary: The who, what, when, and why of Designing for Security in the cloud.
lessons.title: Introduction to Designing for Security

lessons.summary: After this lesson, you will be able to secure access for both AWS users and applications, apply security best practices such as identity federation, and fine tune least privilege access permissions.
lessons.title: Securing Access to Cloud Services

lessons.summary: After this lesson, you will be able to access cloud resources securely, protect against data exfiltration, ensure compliance, and configure VPC endpoints to keep traffic within your VPC.
lessons.title: Securing Access to Cloud Infrastructure

lessons.summary: Our goal is to minimize the risk of a malicious actor accessing our networks and servers, invoke the AWS API, and, ultimately, perform destructive or unauthorized actions in our environments.
lessons.title: Protecting Data Stored in the Cloud

lessons.summary: You will identify vulnerable misconfigurations, guard against malicious activity, and design a deployment pipeline that ensures that security practices are implemented early on.
lessons.title: Defensive Security in the Cloud
Project: Secure the Recipe Vault Web Application

project.title: Securing the Recipe Vault Web Application
project.description:
### Double-check the rubric
Make sure you have completed all the rubric items [here](https://review.udacity.com/#!/rubrics/2800/view).

### Submit your project

You can submit your project as either a zip file or a Github repository link.

## Project Submission Checklist

**Before submitting your project, please review and confirm the following items.** 
<input type="checkbox"> I am confident all rubric items have been met and my project will pass as submitted. (If not, I will discuss with my mentor prior to submitting.)
<input type="checkbox"> Project builds correctly without errors and runs.
<input type="checkbox"> All required functionality exists and my project behaves as expected per the project's specifications.

**Once you have checked all these items, you are ready to submit!**

lessons.summary: Find your next job or connect with industry peers on LinkedIn. Ensure your profile attracts relevant leads that will grow your professional network.
lessons.title: Take 30 Min to Improve your LinkedIn

project.title: Improve Your LinkedIn Profile
project.description:
Have job opportunities come to you by optimizing your LinkedIn profile! Complete this simple process to get personalized tips from a career mentor. 

Here’s how to submit your LinkedIn profile for feedback now:
* Check out this [checklist](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1BZMxuKnBNovOyMelEx7d8ktbsWGj0EJ9KaD81dVC1TE/pub?embedded=true) for tips on optimizing your LinkedIn profile (optional).
* **Make sure your profile is in English.** If you do not have an English profile yet, check out LinkedIn's [advice](https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/1717/creating-or-deleting-a-profile-in-another-language?lang=en) on how to create a secondary language profile.
* Make your profile publicly visible. Scroll down and set the profile section toggles to `Show` under the “Edit Visibility” section of  [your public profile edit page](https://www.linkedin.com/public-profile/settings?trk=nprofile-public-profile-settings-redirect).
 * ![Edit Visibility](http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/R0A5rnKYyzLPZJ8B_pkyxdKkvab5qQi2LnEpFq2L-F33TSgzmjduHuUyDi-Z_ka2L7oU50UYqQTeU1n8VcM=s0#w=400&h=333 "Edit Visibility")
* Create a custom profile URL in the “Edit URL” section of [your public profile edit page](https://www.linkedin.com/public-profile/settings?trk=nprofile-public-profile-settings-redirect).
 * ![Edit URL](http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/SGdIHFzKav0QZmOSrrP69xch_F0Ufhu9pLy-nDXYDArHUyzAen7ewoLakVOKn3KvX_CVgJjBWkl_FmPTPqM=s0#w=250&h=120 "Edit URL")
* Submit your public profile URL (such as `www.linkedin.com/in/udacitystudent`) for guidance from a career mentor by clicking “Submit Project” below.

concepts.title: Use Your Story to Stand Out
Use Your Elevator Pitch on LinkedIn
Create Your Profile With SEO In Mind

lessons.summary: Other professionals are collaborating on GitHub and growing their network. Submit your profile to ensure your profile is on par with leaders in your field.
lessons.title: Optimize Your GitHub Profile

project.title: Optimize Your GitHub Profile
project.description:
GitHub Profiles are a key piece of "evidence" to an employer that you'd be a good job candidate, because they can see the details of your work. Recruiters use GitHub as a way to find job candidates, and many Nanodegree alumni have received work opportunities from their activity on GitHub. In addition, using GitHub is a way for you to collaborate on projects with other programmers - this will show that you are able to work well with others on an engineering team on the job.

## Submission Instructions
1. Submit this project after you've done some continuous coding for two weeks, so the reviewer will be able to comment on trends.
2. Submit your GitHub profile URL as your project.
3. If you'd like to **opt-out** of this project, please read the instructions underneath the divider line, below.

## Project Resources
1. [Project Rubric](https://review.udacity.com/#!/rubrics/52/view). *Your project will be reviewed by a Udacity Career Reviewer against this rubric.*
2. [Project checklist](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1a9AKnNyqfGgdQV5ohPCN5H9ntnEUhMptWMwVBWURCN0/pub?embedded=true). *Based on the project rubric, this is a handy checklist on GitHub best practices.*
3. [Career Resource Center](https://career-resource-center.udacity.com/linkedin-github-profiles). *Find additional tips and guides on developing your GitHub Profile.*

## Up Next
Continue developing on GitHub! For project ideas, consider [contributing to open source](https://career-resource-center.udacity.com/contributing-to-open-source).

---

### *Career Review Requirement*

*Your Nanodegree program was designed to ensure your long-term success in the field, and to pursue a successful career you must showcase the skills you’ve learned to employers effectively. **Therefore, this is a requirement for graduation, unless you opt-out.*** 

#### Opting Out

If improving your GitHub profile does not align with your Nanodegree goals, **you may opt-out of this graduation requirement**.

When you opt-out:

* *You will no longer be able to submit the GitHub Review from this Nanodegree program and all other Nanodegree programs.*
* *Your decision to opt-out is final and future access to GitHub Review will need to be purchased separately.*

*If you would like to opt-out, please click [here](https://forms.udacity.com/forms/career-opt-out).*
project.summary: GitHub is a great way for employers to get a sense of how you code. Learn what your GitHub profile says about you and how to improve it to impress employers.
